citation.article-title: Carboxydocella sporoproducens sp. nov., a novel anaerobic CO-utilizing/H2-producing thermophilic bacterium from a Kamchatka hot spring
citation.source: International Journal of Systematic and Evolutionary Microbiology

p.s: Description of Carboxydocella sporoproducens sp. nov.
Carboxydocella sporoproducens (spo.ro.pro.du′cens. Gr. n. spora a seed and, in biology, a spore; L. part. adj. producens producing; N.L. part. adj. sporoproducens spore-producing).
Has the characteristics of the genus.
Cells are short, straight rods, about 0·5 μm in width and varying in length from 1 to 6 μm.
Cell wall is of the Gram-positive type.
Cells divide by binary transverse fission.
Grows within the temperature range 50–70 °C, with an optimum at 60 °C.
Growth pH ranges from 6·2 to 8·0, with an optimum at pH 6·8.
Grows organoheterotrophically with yeast extract, sucrose or pyruvate under N2 in the gas phase.

Does not grow on peptone, starch, cellobiose, glucose, arabinose, fructose, xylose, galactose, lactose, maltose, glycerol, acetate, citrate, succinate, formate, ethanol or methanol or in an H2/CO2 gas mixture (4 : 1, v/v).
Does not reduce elemental sulfur, sulfate or thiosulfate at the expense of H2, acetate, lactate, glycerol or xylose or during growth with CO.
Elemental sulfur, sulfide and nitrate inhibit growth.
Growth is inhibited by penicillin, novobiocin, streptomycin, kanamycin and neomycin.
The DNA G+C content of the type strain is 49·5±1 mol%.
The type strain, strain KarT (=DSM 16521T=VKM B-2358T), was isolated from a hot spring of Lake Karymskoe on the Kamchatka Peninsula.
